commentary.dadaji: Here Krishna describes the yogi who has arrived — and notice the beauty of how he describes this person. Not 'the one who has accumulated merit' or 'the one who has performed great austerities.' Four qualities: praśānta-manas (the mind deeply stilled), śānta-rajas (the fire of passion cooled), brahma-bhūta (become Brahman — not approaching Brahman, not worshipping Brahman, but become Brahman), and akalmaṣa (without a single blemish). Dadaji would say this last quality — free from blemish — is not about moral perfection in the conventional sense, but about the complete washing away of saṃskāras, the stains left by past actions and desires. And to such a one comes sukham uttamam — the supreme bliss — and notice: it comes (upaiti), it approaches the yogi, as if bliss itself recognizes where its home is.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes that 'brahma-bhūtam' — having become Brahman — is one of the most significant phrases in the Gita, and it recurs in Chapter 18 (verse 54) as the foundation of the highest devotion. To 'become Brahman' does not mean creation of a new identity but the removal of the false one: the ego-self that has superimposed itself on the ātman. When the superimposition is removed through the practices described in the preceding verses, what remains is Brahman — not as something newly acquired but as what always was. The four adjectives applied to this yogi — praśānta-manasam, śānta-rajasam, brahma-bhūtam, akalmaṣam — trace a clear sequence: stilling of mind leads to stilling of passion, which leads to recognition of Brahman-nature, which reveals the natural stainlessness of the Self.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda finds in 'brahma-bhūtam' the key to the entire verse. He explains that there is a crucial difference between the spiritual aspirant who meditates on Brahman as an object of contemplation and the realized yogi who has become Brahman. The former is still the experiencer facing an experience; the latter is the merging of experiencer, experiencing, and experience into a single luminous reality. The order of the four attributes is significant: first the mind must be stilled (praśānta-manas), then the rajasic agitation must subside (śānta-rajas), then the Brahman-nature is recognized (brahma-bhūta), and this recognition reveals the natural purity that was always there but hidden (akalmaṣa). To such a one, sukham uttamam — supreme bliss — does not arrive from outside but wells up from within as the Self's own nature.
commentary.goyandka: The Gita Press commentary treats this verse as the fruit-verse (phala-śruti) for the entire meditation practice described since verse 11. The four compounds — praśānta-manas, śānta-rajas, brahma-bhūta, akalmaṣa — describe the state of the perfected yogi from four angles: psychological (stilled mind), physiological-energetic (quieted rajas), ontological (become Brahman), and moral-spiritual (without blemish). 'Upaiti' — comes to, approaches — suggests that sukham uttamam is not something the yogi creates or achieves through effort; it is something that naturally arrives when the obstacles are removed, like sunlight that floods a room the moment the shutters are opened. The supreme bliss is ever-present; the disciplines merely remove what has been blocking it.

verses.sanskrit:
युञ्जन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी विगतकल्मषः ।
सुखेन ब्रह्मसंस्पर्शमत्यन्तं सुखमश्नुते ॥
verses.transliteration:
yuñjann evaṃ sadātmānaṃ yogī vigata-kalmaṣaḥ
sukhena brahma-saṃsparśam atyantaṃ sukham aśnute
verses.translation: The yogi who persists thus — always turning toward the Divine, every layer of inner impurity gradually dissolved by the sacred fire of practice — reaches with ease and joy the infinite bliss of touching Brahman. Not the effortful, straining touch of the beginner, but the effortless communion of the purified soul who has finally come home to its Source.

word_breakdown.meaning: always engaging / continuously disciplining / unceasingly practising
from whom all impurity has departed / one freed from all blemish
with ease / effortlessly / in comfort — the bliss itself is effortless

word_breakdown.root: brahman (the Absolute) + sam + √spṛś (to touch, to come into contact with)
word_breakdown.meaning: the touch of Brahman / contact with the Absolute / union by touching the Supreme
attains / enjoys / pervades / partakes of

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji's eyes would light up at 'brahma-saṃsparśam' — the touch of Brahman. He used to say: imagine what it is to be touched by the Infinite. Not seen from a distance, not intellectually grasped, not worshipped from afar — touched. Saṃsparśa is an intimate word: it means skin-contact, the feeling of being touched. The mystics of every tradition have described this moment — the moment when the boundary between the individual and the Divine dissolves into a felt union. And notice 'sukhena' — with ease. Not with strain, not after heroic final effort, but with ease. This is because the yogi who has faithfully followed all the preceding instructions has already done the hard work of removal. The touch of Brahman is not something earned — it is something revealed when the obstacles are gone.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda draws attention to the extraordinary word 'brahma-saṃsparśam' — the contact with Brahman, the touch of the Absolute. In Vedantic epistemology, the highest knowledge is aparokṣānubhūti — not mediated, direct, immediate knowing. Saṃsparśa (touch) is the most immediate of all sensory metaphors — closer than seeing, more intimate than hearing. It suggests that the realization of Brahman is not an intellectual conclusion but an immediate, unmediated experience of identity — a knowing that is simultaneously a being. 'Sukhena' — with ease — is the sign that this state is arrived at effortlessly because it is the Self's own nature. It is only the obstacles that take effort to remove; the underlying reality is always here, always easy, always natural.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda considers 'brahma-saṃsparśam' one of the most evocative descriptions of samādhi in the Gita. The word saṃsparśa — touch — is deliberately sensory: it points to an experience that is felt, not merely understood. He recounts from his own experience that the first touch of Brahman in deep meditation feels like being bathed in an ocean of living light — an experience so vast and so intimate simultaneously that the ordinary sense of 'I' and 'other' simply dissolves. 'Sukhena' — with ease — is the sign of genuine divine grace: at the moment of final surrender, all effort ceases, and the soul is simply taken. 'Atyantaṃ sukham aśnute' — enjoys infinite bliss — is not a poetic exaggeration but a statement of direct experience that every true mystic confirms.
commentary.goyandka: The Gita Press commentary carefully distinguishes between two aspects of 'atyantaṃ sukham': the bliss that is atyanta (infinite, absolute) and the mode of its attainment — sukhena (with ease). This is a profound teaching: the bliss of Brahman is not hard to attain in itself, but it becomes easy to attain only for the one who has removed the obstacles through sustained practice (yuñjan evam sadā) and inner purification (vigata-kalmaṣaḥ). The compound 'vigata-kalmaṣaḥ' — from whom impurity has departed — indicates that the purification is complete, not partial. This corresponds to the Vedantic concept of citta-śuddhi as the prerequisite for brahmajñāna. Goyandka notes that 'aśnute' (from √aś, to pervade and enjoy) implies that the yogi does not merely perceive Brahman but pervades it and is pervaded by it — a state of complete mutual indwelling.

verses.sanskrit:
सर्वभूतस्थमात्मानं सर्वभूतानि चात्मनि ।
ईक्षते योगयुक्तात्मा सर्वत्र समदर्शनः ॥
verses.transliteration:
sarva-bhūtastham ātmānaṃ sarva-bhūtāni cātmani
īkṣate yoga-yuktātmā sarvatra sama-darśanaḥ
verses.translation: The soul made radiant through yoga perceives — with the clear, astonished eyes of the Spirit — the one indwelling Self present in every living being, and every being cradled within that same infinite Self. This vision of unity is not a poetic idea but the direct experience of the awakened heart: God in all, all in God, everywhere and always the same divine Presence.

word_breakdown.root: sarva (all) + bhūta (being, creature) + √sthā (to stand, to abide)
word_breakdown.meaning: abiding in all beings / dwelling in every creature / present in all that exists
sees / beholds / perceives — with the force of direct spiritual vision
one whose self is made perfect through yoga / the yogi whose self is fully united

word_breakdown.root: sama (equal, same, even) + darśana (seeing, vision, beholding)
word_breakdown.meaning: one of equal vision / who sees all with the same eye / who beholds the same in all

commentary.dadaji: This verse is the flower that blooms when the samādhi described in the preceding verses ripens into permanent wisdom. Dadaji called this verse the vision of the saint in daily life: when the yogi comes out of deep meditation, the world looks different. Not different in its surface appearances — the cow is still a cow, the stone a stone — but the light within everything is seen. 'Sarva-bhūtastham ātmānam' — the Self dwelling in all beings — and 'sarva-bhūtāni cātmani' — all beings in the Self. This is not a philosophical belief; it is direct perception, described by 'īkṣate.' And the practical consequence: 'sarvatra sama-darśanaḥ' — seeing everywhere with equal eyes. Not equal in the sense of ignoring differences, but equal in recognizing the same divine presence in the saint and the sinner, the beautiful and the ugly, the friend and the enemy.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda identifies this verse as the Gita's most explicit statement of the non-dual vision — what the Upaniṣads call sarvam khalv idaṃ brahma (all this is indeed Brahman). The two complementary perceptions — 'sarva-bhūtastham ātmānam' (the Self in all beings) and 'sarva-bhūtāni cātmani' (all beings in the Self) — represent the two directions of the non-dual vision: looking outward, the yogi sees the one Self everywhere; looking inward, the yogi sees the entire universe within the Self. This is the Vedantic seer's vision described in the Īśā Upaniṣad: 'He who sees all beings in the Self and the Self in all beings loses all hatred.' The practical-ethical consequence is 'sama-darśana' — equal vision — the fruit of wisdom.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda sees this verse as the description of what he calls the 'cosmic consciousness' experience — the state in which the individual consciousness expands to encompass all existence. 'Yoga-yuktātmā' — the self perfected through yoga — is the key qualifier: this is not a temporary mystical experience but the permanent state of the fully realized yogi. 'Sarvatra sama-darśanaḥ' — equal vision everywhere — does not mean the yogi becomes indifferent to distinctions, but that beneath all differences the yogi perceives the one Presence, the one Self, playing all the roles of the cosmic drama. He relates this to his own experience of cosmic consciousness described in his autobiography — the experience in which the walls of the room expanded to contain the universe and the universe was felt as one's own Self.
commentary.goyandka: The Gita Press commentary treats this verse as the description of jīvanmukti — liberation while still embodied — in its experiential dimension. The phrase 'yoga-yuktātmā' — one whose ātman is properly united through yoga — indicates that this is the fruit specifically of the dhyāna yoga taught in this chapter, not a gift that arrives independently of practice. The verse describes a double vision: upward (the Self in all beings) and downward (all beings in the Self) — like seeing both the gold in every ornament and every ornament as gold. 'Sama-darśanaḥ' (equal vision) does not deny the empirical differences between beings — a blade of grass and a human being are empirically different — but it affirms that at the level of ultimate reality, both are expressions of the one Self, and the realized yogi sees this directly.

verses.sanskrit:
यो मां पश्यति सर्वत्र सर्वं च मयि पश्यति ।
तस्याहं न प्रणश्यामि स च मे न प्रणश्यति ॥
verses.transliteration:
yo māṃ paśyati sarvatra sarvaṃ ca mayi paśyati
tasyāhaṃ na praṇaśyāmi sa ca me na praṇaśyati
verses.translation: He who sees Me shining in every face and beholds all creation resting within Me — between that soul and God no shadow of separation can ever fall again. I am never hidden from him, says the Divine, and he can never be lost to Me. This is the eternal promise spoken from the Heart of all hearts: the love between the awakened soul and God is mutual, absolute, and forever.

word_breakdown.root: sarva (all) + tra (locative suffix meaning 'in all places')
word_breakdown.meaning: everywhere / in all places / throughout all existence
in Me / within Me / inside the Divine

word_breakdown.root: pra + √naś (to perish, to be lost, to disappear)
word_breakdown.meaning: am lost / disappear / become invisible — here negated: am never lost

word_breakdown.root: pra + √naś (to perish, to be lost, to disappear)
word_breakdown.meaning: is lost / disappears / becomes invisible — here negated: is never lost to Me

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji considered this one of the most moving verses in the entire Gita, and he would read it very quietly, almost as a whisper. 'Tasyāhaṃ na praṇaśyāmi sa ca me na praṇaśyati' — I am never lost to him, and he is never lost to Me. This is the divine promise, the assurance of eternal, unbreakable relationship between the soul and God. Dadaji would say: most of us fear that God has forgotten us, that we are somehow not important enough, not pure enough, not deserving of the divine presence. This verse destroys that fear forever. If you can see Krishna — the Divine — in everything and everything in the Divine, then you are held. You are seen. You are never lost, even for a moment. And God is never hidden from you. The mystical relationship is permanent, mutual, and unconditional.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda reads this verse as the personal, devotional expression of the non-dual vision described in verse 29. Verse 29 is in the third person — the yogi sees the Self in all. Verse 30 is in the first person — Krishna speaks directly, personally: I am never lost to him, and he is never lost to Me. This shift from philosophical description to personal address is significant: the non-dual vision is not a cold abstraction but a living relationship. 'Na praṇaśyāmi' — I do not become lost — is a divine guarantee. 'Praṇaśyati' (from pra + √naś) means to vanish, to be destroyed, to become invisible. The one who has attained sama-darśana can never lose sight of the Divine, because they have recognized the Divine as the very substance of their own seeing.
commentary.yogananda: For Yogananda, this verse is the supreme devotional promise in the Gita — the moment where philosophical teaching gives way to the voice of divine love. He writes that these words of Krishna are addressed to every sincere meditator, in every age. The one who trains their inner eye to see the Divine everywhere — in the flower, the storm, the stranger, the moment of suffering and the moment of joy — that one will never lose God. And equally, Krishna says, God will never lose that devotee: 'sa ca me na praṇaśyati' — he is never lost to Me. Yogananda found this verse profoundly consoling: even when the meditator is beset by doubts, distractions, and spiritual dryness, they are still in God's sight. The relationship, once established, is eternal.
commentary.goyandka: The Gita Press commentary reads this verse as the culmination of the entire Chapter 6 teaching and the transition to Chapter 7, which opens with bhakti-jñāna (devotion united with knowledge). The reciprocal structure — 'tasyāhaṃ na praṇaśyāmi / sa ca me na praṇaśyati' — mirrors the reciprocal vision of verse 29 (Self in all, all in Self) but at the personal level of the Divine-devotee relationship. Goyandka notes that the word 'praṇaśyati' (not merely 'naśyati' but with the prefix 'pra' intensifying the meaning) emphasizes complete, absolute invisibility — which is what is being negated. There is no possibility, however slight, of the realized devotee losing sight of Krishna or of Krishna losing sight of the devotee. This mutual seeing — the Divine beholding the devotee, the devotee beholding the Divine — is the essence of the bhakta's relationship with God.

verses.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
सर्वभूतस्थितं यो मां भजत्येकत्वमास्थितः ।
सर्वथा वर्तमानोऽपि स योगी मयि वर्तते ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
sarva-bhūta-sthitaṃ yo māṃ bhajatyekatvam āsthitaḥ
sarvathā vartamāno 'pi sa yogī mayi vartate
verses.translation: The Lord declares: That blessed yogi who, rooted in the experience of oneness, worships Me as the one indwelling Reality in every creature — that soul lives always in Me, whatever the outer form of life may be. In cooking and teaching, in silence and in service, every moment becomes a continuous prayer to the One who dwells in all. Such a one has transcended religion and entered Reality.

word_breakdown.meaning: abiding in all beings — one who dwells within every creature without exception
non-duality / oneness — the state of seeing only the One in all multiplicity

word_breakdown.grammatical_form: Past passive participle, masculine, nominative, singular
word_breakdown.meaning: established in / grounded in — one who is firmly settled in that oneness

word_breakdown.root: √bhaj (to worship, to adore, to share in)
word_breakdown.meaning: worships / adores — offers loving devotion; not ritual worship but continual communion
abides / lives / exists — dwells in; the yogi's every moment is a living within the Divine

commentary.dadaji: This verse is the crown of the whole chapter, my dear. Baba used to say, 'When you truly see Bhagwan in each face, you never leave His lap.' The word ekatvam is so beautiful — it does not mean sameness in appearance, but oneness in essence. When you worship the Lord as dwelling in all — the beggar at your door, the crow on the wire, the child crying in the night — you yourself enter into the Lord. Notice 'sarvathā vartamāno 'pi' — even while going about all duties, cooking, working, quarreling perhaps — still the yogi lives in Me, says Krishna. The devotional act of bhajati here is not chanting alone; it is the heart's steady recognition. This is the fruit of dhyana: you stop seeing 'others.' What a gift Bhagwan gives in this one shloka.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse expresses the pinnacle of the Advaita realization within bhakti. Ekatvam āsthitaḥ — established in non-duality. The yogi sees sarva-bhūta-sthitaṃ māṃ — Me, the Lord, abiding in all beings. This is not pantheism but the Vedantic truth that Brahman, the one Self, underlies all apparent multiplicity. The Māṇḍūkya Upaniṣad declares: 'All this is Brahman.' When worship flows from this non-dual understanding, there is no worshipper separate from the worshipped. 'Sarvathā vartamāno 'pi sa yogī mayi vartate' — regardless of external activity, he lives in Me. This integrates jñāna and bhakti perfectly. The outer world does not disturb him, for he sees no outer world separate from the Self.
commentary.yogananda: In the language of divine realization, ekatvam — cosmic oneness — is the direct perception of God as the one Life pulsating through every atom. Paramahansaji taught that the advanced devotee literally sees the Light of Brahman shining through all faces. 'Sarva-bhūta-sthitaṃ māṃ' is not metaphor; it is mystical fact, perceived in the highest states of samādhi and then retained even in waking consciousness. The ordinary person lives in delusion, seeing separateness; the yogi, awakened through meditation, sees unity. 'Sarvathā vartamāno 'pi' — though moving through all conditions — the inner vision never wavers. Such a one has transcended the oscillating states of the mind and lives perpetually in the cosmic AUM, in the omnipresent Christ Consciousness.
commentary.goyandka: Bhagavan here defines the highest yogi — one established in ekatvam, non-difference. This means seeing Paramātmā as the indwelling Reality in all jīvas. He worships that all-pervading Lord through the recognition of His presence everywhere. The phrase 'sarvathā vartamāno 'pi' — though living in all manner of ways — indicates that external circumstances are irrelevant once the inner vision is established. Such a devotee, even while performing worldly duties, never actually leaves the Lord, for his consciousness remains anchored in the divine omnipresence. This verse crowns the previous descriptions of the realized yogi and shows that the acme of yoga is not withdrawal from the world but the constant living awareness of the Lord's all-pervasive presence.

verses.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
आत्मौपम्येन सर्वत्र समं पश्यति योऽर्जुन ।
सुखं वा यदि वा दुःखं स योगी परमो मतः ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
ātmaupamyena sarvatra samaṃ paśyati yo 'rjuna
sukhaṃ vā yadi vā duḥkhaṃ sa yogī paramo mataḥ
verses.translation: The Divine Teacher declares: He who, measuring all by the standard of his own soul's longing for joy and shrinking from pain, sees every being's happiness and suffering as his own — who beholds this sacred equality everywhere without exception — that yogi stands among the highest, dearest to My heart, O Arjuna. This universal empathy is love made perfect.

word_breakdown.meaning: by comparison with oneself — using one's own experience as the measuring rod for all others
equality / sameness — the even vision that sees the same essential reality in all
sees / perceives — an active, living perception, not merely an intellectual belief
the highest / supreme — the pinnacle among all yogis; none is greater

word_breakdown.grammatical_form: Past passive participle, masculine, nominative, singular
word_breakdown.meaning: considered / regarded — Krishna's own verdict; this is the Lord's direct assessment

commentary.dadaji: Ātmaupamyena — by comparison with oneself. This is the simplest and most beautiful teaching on compassion in the whole Gita. Feel your own joy, feel your own pain — and know that every creature feels exactly thus. When that knowing becomes real, not borrowed from a book, you stop hurting others automatically. The yogi of this verse does not need rules to be kind; he simply cannot be unkind, because he sees himself in everyone. And Bhagwan says such a one is 'paramo' — the very highest. Not the one who sits longest in meditation, but the one who has most fully erased the line between 'self' and 'other.' This is the final test of all spiritual practice, my child.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Ātmaupamyena — the method is striking in its practicality. The Vedanta says 'tat tvam asi — that thou art'; here Krishna gives the experiential method: use your own felt experience of joy and suffering as the universal yardstick. You know your own pain intimately; extend that same knowing to others. This is how the abstract teaching of oneness becomes compassionate action. Note that paśyati is in the present tense — it is a living perception, not a past realization filed away. The highest yogi is perpetually, actively seeing this equality. The Upaniṣad asks: 'Who sees all beings in the Self and the Self in all beings — from that person, what delusion, what sorrow can there be?'
commentary.yogananda: The greatest yogi, says Krishna, is the one who has awakened to the universality of feeling. In the superconscious state of samādhi, the boundaries of the ego dissolve and one literally feels the joy and suffering of all creation as one's own. This is not mere sentiment; it is the cosmic empathy of Christ Consciousness. Ātmaupamyena — through the measure of the Self — means the realized master uses the expanded Self as the measuring rod, not the small ego-self. Yoganandaji wrote that such a one becomes an instrument of Divine Love, effortlessly serving all because he has ceased to see any separation between his own soul and the souls of others. This equality-vision is samādhi lived in the marketplace.
commentary.goyandka: This verse describes the sādhana of samadarśitā — equal vision — in its most concrete form. The instruction 'ātmaupamyena' provides a practical method: as you yourself desire happiness and shrink from pain, so does every being. This empathic recognition, extended universally, becomes the foundation of true non-injury and genuine service. Such a yogi never harms another knowingly, for he understands from within what harm means. Bhagavan himself declares this yogi 'paramo mataḥ' — the highest in My estimation. This places equal vision above mere tapas, scholarship, or ritual purity. It is the culmination of all inner development and the living expression of the realization of the one Ātman in all.

verses.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच ।
योऽयं योगस्त्वया प्रोक्तः साम्येन मधुसूदन ।
एतस्याहं न पश्यामि चञ्चलत्वात् स्थितिं स्थिराम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca
yo 'yaṃ yogas tvayā proktaḥ sāmyena madhusūdana
etasyāhaṃ na paśyāmi cañcalatvāt sthitiṃ sthirām
verses.translation: Arjuna, the sincere soul, confesses to Krishna: O Slayer of Madhu, this yoga of perfect equanimity that You have revealed fills me with longing — yet I cannot see how to stand firm upon it. The mind, so restless, so fickle, seems to offer no stable ground beneath these lofty teachings. How does the soul find its footing when the very instrument of practice is in constant motion?

word_breakdown.meaning: by equality / through equanimity — the yoga characterized by the equal vision just described

word_breakdown.root: madhu (the demon Madhu) + √sūd (to destroy, to slay)
word_breakdown.grammatical_form: Masculine noun, vocative, singular (epithet of Krishna)
word_breakdown.meaning: O Slayer of the demon Madhu — Arjuna invokes Krishna's power to destroy obstacles, hinting that the mind's restlessness is his own demon
because of restlessness — ablative of cause; the mind's oscillating, unsteady nature is the very obstacle

word_breakdown.root: √sthā (to stand, to remain, to be stable)
word_breakdown.meaning: foundation / stability / steadiness — a firm resting place; the inability to find such a place is Arjuna's complaint
steady / firm / stable — qualifies sthitiṃ; he cannot find even a stable stability, as it were

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna speaks here for every one of us, and that is precisely why these verses are so precious. He has just heard the most sublime teaching — the yogi who sees oneness, who feels others' joy and pain — and his immediate, honest response is: 'I cannot do this. My mind will not sit still.' What I love is the name he uses: Madhusudana, Slayer of the demon Madhu. Unconsciously, he is calling on Krishna to slay the demon of his own restless mind. God always answers such prayers. And notice — Arjuna does not pretend. He does not say 'Yes, I understand.' He says 'I do not see how this can be steadily established.' This honesty before the Guru is itself a great spiritual act.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Arjuna's objection is the objection of every sincere student. The yoga of sāmya — equal vision — sounds beautiful in theory. But the mind, the instrument through which this vision must arise, is itself cañcala — restless, perpetually oscillating between attraction and repulsion. Without a steady mind, there can be no steady vision of equality. This is a real philosophical problem, not mere weakness. The Kaṭha Upaniṣad compares the Self to the passenger in the chariot, the buddhi to the charioteer, and the mind to the reins — if the reins are slack, the horses run wild. Arjuna is honestly reporting: his reins are slack. This confession sets up Krishna's practical and compassionate answer in the following verses.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna gives voice to the universal human predicament. The divine vision of oneness is perceived in glimpses during meditation — moments of breathtaking clarity when the boundaries of self dissolve — but then the mind reasserts itself and the vision vanishes. Cañcalatvāt — because of restlessness — this is the root affliction of the unawakened nervous system. Yoganandaji taught that this restlessness is caused by the outward-flowing life force (prāṇa) dispersed through the senses. Until prāṇa is interiorized through kriyā practice, the mind cannot maintain steady samādhi. Arjuna's complaint is not defeatism; it is the essential question that brings out Krishna's answer about abhyāsa and vairāgya — the twin pillars of yogic training.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's question is of universal importance. Having understood the ideal yoga of equal vision, he frankly confesses his inability to achieve it due to the mind's inherent instability. The use of 'cañcalatvāt' — ablative of cause — is significant: it identifies the precise obstacle. The mind is not merely occasionally disturbed; its very nature is oscillation, as its root cañc (to move to and fro) indicates. Arjuna is asking not out of laziness but out of genuine inquiry: given this nature of the mind, how can the 'sthiti sthirā' — the steady resting place — ever be achieved? This question compels Krishna to give his most practical and accessible teaching in verses 35 and 36.

verses.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच ।
चञ्चलं हि मनः कृष्ण प्रमाथि बलवद् दृढम् ।
तस्याहं निग्रहं मन्ये वायोरिव सुदुष्करम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca
cañcalaṃ hi manaḥ kṛṣṇa pramāthi balavad dṛḍham
tasyāhaṃ nigrahaṃ manye vāyor iva su-duṣkaram
verses.translation: O Krishna, the mind is restless — this I know from the depths of my own experience. It churns and torments without ceasing, powerful as a storm, stubborn as stone. To bring such a force under the soul's quiet governance seems as impossible as grasping the wind with bare hands. Yet You ask this of me — tell me, beloved Lord, how it can be done.

word_breakdown.root: pra + √math (to churn, to agitate, to torment)
word_breakdown.meaning: turbulent / tormenting — one that churns and agitates; the mind actively disturbs and churns all one's good intentions
powerful / forceful — possessed of great strength; the mind's pull toward objects is not a weak inclination but a powerful current

word_breakdown.root: √dṛh (to be firm, to be fixed, to be obstinate)
word_breakdown.meaning: obstinate / rigid / stubborn — the mind resists efforts to discipline it with a stiff tenacity

word_breakdown.root: ni + √grah (to hold, to restrain, to seize)
word_breakdown.meaning: restraint / control — the act of holding the mind back from its outward rush; the object of Arjuna's attempt

word_breakdown.root: su (intensifier: very) + duṣkara (difficult to do, duṣ + √kṛ)
word_breakdown.meaning: exceedingly difficult — not merely hard but supremely difficult, as if impossible by one's own unaided effort

commentary.dadaji: Four words Arjuna uses — cañcalaṃ, pramāthi, balavat, dṛḍham — and each one is true. Have you tried to sit quietly for even five minutes? The mind jumps to tomorrow's worries, yesterday's insults, tonight's dinner. And then Arjuna gives the most beautiful comparison: like trying to hold the wind. You cannot grab wind in your fist; it slips through. So does the mind — the harder you squeeze, the more it escapes. But Baba used to smile at this verse and say: 'The one who knows the mind is like the wind is already half a yogi. Most people don't even know they have a mind running wild.' This recognition is not defeat — it is the beginning of real sādhana.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Arjuna adds four devastating adjectives: cañcalaṃ — restless; pramāthi — turbulent, it churns everything it touches; balavat — powerful, its pull toward sense objects has enormous force; and dṛḍham — obstinate, it does not easily yield to discipline. The vāyu comparison is philosophically apt. In the subtle body, the mind and prāṇa are intimately connected — where prāṇa goes, the mind follows, and vice versa. Controlling the mind is indeed like catching the wind, because both the mind and vāyu are subtle, pervasive, and formless. The Haṭhayoga Pradīpikā says: 'When prāṇa moves, chitta moves; when prāṇa is still, chitta is still.' This gives us the key to what Krishna will prescribe.
commentary.yogananda: Pramāthi — this word is extraordinary. It means the mind not only wanders but actively torments, churns, agitates. Anyone who has sat in meditation and watched the mind drag up ancient memories, project future fears, construct elaborate fantasies — knows this churning firsthand. Balavat dṛḍham — powerful and stubborn. Yoganandaji used to say the mind is like an untrained monkey stung by a scorpion: jumping, screeching, wildly erratic. The wind comparison points to the need for a subtle technology of control — you cannot wrestle with the wind; you must work with it. In kriyā yoga, the prāṇa-mind complex is redirected through the spine's subtle channels rather than forcibly suppressed, and this is the only truly effective method.
commentary.goyandka: In this verse, Arjuna elaborates his concern from verse 33 by piling up four powerful epithets for the mind. Together they form a complete description of the mind's nature as an obstacle to yoga. Cañcalaṃ: its essential character is oscillation. Pramāthi: it actively disrupts even the wisdom one has accumulated. Balavat: it overpowers the discriminative intellect. Dṛḍham: its habits are deeply entrenched and resist reform. The wind metaphor is well-chosen; just as one cannot grasp and hold wind in one's hand, one cannot forcibly suppress the mind through brute willpower alone. This prepares the ground for Krishna's answer, which speaks of gradual practice and dispassion as the appropriate methods — working with the mind's nature rather than against it.

verses.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
असंशयं महाबाहो मनो दुर्निग्रहं चलम् ।
अभ्यासेन तु कौन्तेय वैराग्येण च गृह्यते ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
asaṃśayaṃ mahā-bāho mano durnigrahaṃ calam
abhyāsena tu kaunteya vairāgyeṇa ca gṛhyate
verses.translation: The Divine Friend answers with compassion: Yes, O mighty-armed Arjuna — the mind is indeed restless and hard to govern. I acknowledge the truth of what you have said. And yet — by two wings the soul learns to soar above the mind's turbulence: sustained, devoted practice that returns again and again to the inner Source, and the gradual blossoming of dispassion toward the world's hollow promises. With these two, the mind is mastered.

word_breakdown.grammatical_form: Neuter noun used adverbially, accusative, singular
word_breakdown.meaning: without doubt / undoubtedly — Krishna begins by fully validating Arjuna's observation; this is not weakness but truth

word_breakdown.root: dur (with difficulty) + ni + √grah (to hold, to restrain)
word_breakdown.meaning: difficult to restrain / hard to control — Krishna concedes the mind's stubbornness while implying it is not impossible

word_breakdown.root: abhi + √as (to throw, to practice) — repetitive application
word_breakdown.meaning: by practice / through repeated effort — the instrumental case indicates the method; consistent, sustained repetition of the chosen discipline

word_breakdown.root: vi + rāga (passion, color, attachment) — freedom from coloring
word_breakdown.meaning: by dispassion / through non-attachment — the progressive loosening of the mind's fascination with sense objects

word_breakdown.grammatical_form: Present tense, passive voice, 3rd person singular
word_breakdown.meaning: is restrained / is held — passive construction: through these means, the mind becomes controlled; the process is gradual and sure

commentary.dadaji: See how Krishna begins: 'Asaṃśayam' — without doubt. He does not scold Arjuna. He does not say 'You are weak, you should be stronger.' He says: Yes, you are right, the mind is indeed very hard to control. This is the compassion of a true teacher. Then comes the answer — just two words: abhyāsa and vairāgya. Practice and dispassion. Not miracles, not special powers — just daily, patient, loving practice. Like learning to ride a bicycle. You fall, you get back on. And vairāgya — not hatred of the world, but simply not clinging to it. When Baba explained vairāgya he said: 'Enjoy the rose, but do not try to own it.' That is enough.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Krishna's reply is a masterpiece of pedagogical compassion and philosophical precision. First, He validates: asaṃśayam — without doubt, the mind is durnigraham, hard to restrain. There is no shame in finding this difficult. Then He gives the two pillars of mental mastery: abhyāsa and vairāgya. These same two are prescribed at the very opening of Patañjali's practical teaching in the Yoga Sūtras (1.12): 'abhyāsa-vairāgyābhyāṃ tan-nirodhaḥ — by practice and dispassion comes the cessation of mental fluctuations.' Abhyāsa means the consistent, repeated turning of the mind back toward the chosen object of meditation. Vairāgya means the steady reduction of the mind's interest in sensory objects. Together they work: abhyāsa gives the mind something wholesome to cling to; vairāgya loosens its grip on the unwholesome.
commentary.yogananda: Krishna's two-word prescription — abhyāsa and vairāgya — encapsulates the entire science of raja yoga. Abhyāsa is the positive pole: the daily, devoted practice of meditation, of returning the mind to its source. Vairāgya is the negative pole: the withdrawal of interest from the flickering attractions of the senses. These two create the tension within which the mind is gradually mastered — like two oars rowing a boat in tandem. Yoganandaji emphasized that vairāgya is not world-hatred but world-transcendence. The vairāgī still lives in the world but is no longer enslaved by it. And abhyāsa, in the kriyā context, means the specific technique that withdraws the life force from the senses and focuses it at the spiritual eye — the most effective of all practices for mental mastery.
commentary.goyandka: This verse is foundational for all sincere spiritual aspirants. Krishna first confirms the difficulty Arjuna has described — this is not false encouragement but honest acknowledgment. Then He gives the two universal means: abhyāsa (practice) and vairāgya (dispassion). Abhyāsa is defined in the Yoga Sūtras as the effort toward steadiness, pursued long, without interruption, and with earnestness. Vairāgya is the mastery over craving — the progressive reduction of the mind's thirst for sensory objects. Together these two are sufficient. No special birth, no extraordinary grace, no esoteric technique is required beyond these. The word 'gṛhyate' — is restrained — in the passive voice is significant: through these means, the restraint happens; it is not forced but naturally achieved.

verses.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
असंयतात्मना योगो दुष्प्राप इति मे मतिः ।
वश्यात्मना तु यतता शक्योऽवाप्तुमुपायतः ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
asaṃyatātmanā yogo duṣprāpa iti me matiḥ
vaśyātmanā tu yatatā śakyo 'vāptum upāyataḥ
verses.translation: For the soul whose inner life is not yet disciplined — scattered by the senses, driven by desire — yoga remains elusive, like a distant horizon. This is My honest truth to you, says the Lord. Yet for the one who takes the reins of the self into steady hands and strives with the right methods, yoga becomes not merely possible but certain. The door is open to every soul who truly knocks.

word_breakdown.root: a (not) + saṃyata (controlled, restrained, from sam + √yam) + ātman (self)
word_breakdown.meaning: by one whose self is uncontrolled — the person who has not yet brought the senses and mind under discipline

word_breakdown.root: duṣ (with difficulty) + pra + √āp (to reach, to attain)
word_breakdown.meaning: difficult to attain — not impossible, but requiring serious effort; duṣ indicates difficulty, not impossibility
by one whose self is controlled / subdued — the counterpart to asaṃyatātmanā; the disciplined practitioner

word_breakdown.root: √yat (to strive, to endeavor, to make effort)
word_breakdown.meaning: by one who strives / by the earnest seeker — effort is indispensable; self-control alone without striving is insufficient
through proper means / by right method — yoga is not attained by any random effort but by the correct methods described

commentary.dadaji: Krishna is both encouraging and honest in this verse. He does not say yoga is impossible for the uncontrolled person — He says it is duṣprāpa, difficult to reach. There is hope in that word. And then see the beautiful construction: 'vaśyātmanā tu yatatā śakyo 'vāptum upāyataḥ' — by the one with a controlled self who strives through right means, it can be attained. Two conditions: self-control and right striving. Upāyataḥ — through proper means. This means the Guru's guidance matters; one must learn the correct method. Random tapasya or self-invented practices may not serve. Seek a teacher, follow the path, and practice consistently — yoga will come. Krishna guarantees it.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse completes the thought of verse 35. Krishna now frames the matter as a clear logical contrast. The uncontrolled self — asaṃyatātmā — will find yoga duṣprāpa, very hard to reach. Here 'self' (ātman) in this compound refers not to the supreme Self but to the jīvātman, the individual, with its instruments of mind and senses. The self-controlled person — vaśyātmā — who additionally yatata (strives) and uses upāya (right means), will find it śakya (possible, achievable). Note the particle 'tu' — but — which turns the verse from potentially discouraging to deeply encouraging. Self-control is developed through abhyāsa and vairāgya just described; right means includes all the preliminary disciplines of the Gita.
commentary.yogananda: Asaṃyatātmanā — by the uncontrolled self — this refers to one who allows prāṇa to flow outward freely through the sense doors. Such a person sits for meditation but the mind follows the prāṇa outward and there is no real interiorization. Vaśyātmanā — by the controlled self — this is the practitioner who has learned to withdraw prāṇa at will, who can close the sense doors not by brute suppression but by the magnetic attraction of inner bliss. Upāyataḥ — through proper means — points to the scientific technique. Yoganandaji was emphatic: any sincere seeker who applies the right technique consistently will attain yoga. It is not a lottery; it is a science with guaranteed results for the sincere practitioner.
commentary.goyandka: The word 'upāyataḥ' — through proper means — is especially significant in this verse. It indicates that yoga is not attained through mere desire, nor through haphazard effort, but through the intelligent application of prescribed methods. These means include yama-niyama (ethical discipline), āsana, prāṇāyāma, pratyāhāra, and the dhāraṇā-dhyāna-samādhi sequence described throughout this chapter. Me matiḥ — this is My view — Krishna takes personal responsibility for this statement, lending it the weight of divine authority. For those who worry whether yoga is achievable at all, this verse is the Lord's direct assurance: with self-mastery and right effort, it is certainly attainable.

verses.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच ।
अयतिः श्रद्धयोपेतो योगाच्चलितमानसः ।
अप्राप्य योगसंसिद्धिं कां गतिं कृष्ण गच्छति ॥
verses.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca
ayatiḥ śraddhayopeto yogāc calita-mānasaḥ
aprāpya yoga-saṃsiddhiṃ kāṃ gatiṃ kṛṣṇa gacchati
verses.translation: Arjuna asks with the anxiety of every sincere seeker: O Krishna, what of the soul who genuinely believed — who turned toward the path of yoga with true faith — yet whose effort fell short, whose mind wandered from the practice before perfection was reached? What becomes of such a one? Has the aspiration been wasted? Has the love been lost? This is the question that has haunted every devoted heart.

word_breakdown.meaning: one who does not strive enough / the non-striver — not a faithless person, but one whose effort falls short of completion

word_breakdown.root: śraddhā (faith, trust) + upa + √i (to go, to be endowed with)
word_breakdown.meaning: endowed with faith — genuinely believing in yoga and in God; the problem is not lack of faith but lack of sustained effort
one whose mind has wandered from yoga — who started the path but was deflected by distractions or circumstances

word_breakdown.root: yoga + sam + √sidh (to succeed, to be perfected)
word_breakdown.meaning: perfection in yoga / the fullness of yogic accomplishment — the complete realization; not progress but the final fruit

word_breakdown.root: √gam (to go, to move) — the path one takes
word_breakdown.meaning: destination / end / fate — the path or state attained after death; the ultimate trajectory of the soul

commentary.dadaji: This is the question that makes every ordinary person's heart quicken — because most of us are exactly this: we have faith, we want God, we even practice for some time — and then life comes. Illness, family duties, laziness, doubt. The practice slips. Are we then condemned? Arjuna is asking this on behalf of all of us imperfect seekers, and it is one of the most loving questions in the entire Gita. Notice — this person has śraddhā, genuine faith. He is not a hypocrite or an unbeliever. He simply did not complete the journey this time. Krishna's answer in verse 40 will bring tears of relief to every such person.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This is one of the most poignant and practically important questions of the Gita. Arjuna describes a specific type of sādhaka: śraddhayopetaḥ — possessed of genuine faith, not a doubter or a worldly person; ayatiḥ — yet one who did not persevere sufficiently; calita-mānasaḥ — whose mind wandered from the path. Such a person, aprāpya yoga-saṃsiddhim — not having attained the fullness of yoga — what becomes of them? This is the anxiety of every sincere but struggling practitioner. The Vedantic question behind it is: does spiritual effort have cumulative, trans-life value? Krishna will answer with an unequivocal and deeply comforting yes.
commentary.yogananda: This question could only come from Arjuna's compassionate heart. He is not asking for himself alone but for the countless sincere souls who begin the spiritual journey, make genuine progress, and then are cut short — by an untimely death, by an overwhelming temptation, by the sheer force of accumulated karma. Śraddhayopetaḥ — faith is present; yoga-saṃsiddhiṃ aprāpya — but perfection was not reached. Is all that effort wasted? Yoganandaji used to say this is the most reassuring passage in all scripture for the struggling devotee, because Krishna's answer makes it utterly clear that no sincere spiritual effort is ever lost or wasted. The soul carries its attainments from life to life.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna presents a case of great practical importance: the sādhaka who possesses the most important qualification — śraddhā, faith — but who falls short due to insufficient effort or due to the mind's wandering. He asks: kāṃ gatiṃ gacchati — what destination does such a person reach? The question implies a fear that such a person, having abandoned worldly pursuit without completing the spiritual path, might be 'lost' — falling between two worlds. This fear motivates the question. The pair of verses 37-38 together present a complete portrait of this fallen yogi's predicament. Krishna's comprehensive answer will be given in verses 40-45 and will fully resolve the anxiety.

verses.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच ।
कच्चिन्नोभयविभ्रष्टश्छिन्नाभ्रमिव नश्यति ।
अप्रतिष्ठो महाबाहो विमूढो ब्रह्मणः पथि ॥
verses.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca
kaccin nobhaya-vibhraṣṭaś chinnābhram iva naśyati
apratiṣṭho mahā-bāho vimūḍho brahmaṇaḥ pathi
verses.translation: Fallen from the world he left behind, not yet arrived at the God he sought — does such a soul perish like a wisp of cloud torn from the sky, without enough substance to become rain, drifting and fading into nothing? Without footing in either realm, confused on the luminous path to Brahman — is this the fate of the sincere but incomplete seeker? My heart trembles at the thought.

word_breakdown.root: ubhaya (both) + vi + √bhraṃś (to fall, to slip, to be dislodged)
word_breakdown.meaning: fallen from both — from worldly life (abandoned for yoga) and from yoga (not yet perfected); stranded in between
a torn / severed cloud — a fragment broken off from the main cloud-mass, with no substance of its own; a vivid image of purposeless drifting

word_breakdown.root: a (not) + prati + √sthā (to stand) — lacking a firm base
word_breakdown.meaning: without support / without a firm footing — having no stable ground in either worldly achievement or spiritual realization

word_breakdown.root: vi (intensifier) + √muh (to be confused, to be deluded)
word_breakdown.grammatical_form: Past passive participle, masculine, nominative, singular
word_breakdown.meaning: utterly confused / thoroughly deluded — disoriented on the path, unable to find direction in the spiritual journey
on the path to Brahman — the great spiritual highway leading to liberation; the path the seeker has set out upon but not yet traversed

commentary.dadaji: The image of the torn cloud is so poignant. A small cloud that breaks off from the main cloud has no weight to fall as rain, no size to linger — it simply evaporates, scattered by the wind, becoming nothing. Arjuna is asking: is the fallen yogi like this? Gone from the world, not yet arrived at God, adrift — does he simply dissolve? And 'apratiṣṭho' — without any footing. Nowhere to stand. This is the fear of the spiritual seeker who has left behind the familiar securities of worldly life. But notice — Arjuna already seems to sense the answer will be reassuring, because he phrases it as a question: 'does he not perish?' He is hoping Krishna will say 'No.' And Krishna will.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The chinnābhram — torn cloud — simile is philosophically rich. A cloud that is severed from its formation has no coherence; it disperses and vanishes. Arjuna fears this is the fate of the yogi who has cut ties with worldly dharma to pursue liberation, but then fails to reach liberation. Ubhaya-vibhraṣṭaḥ — fallen from both worlds. From the worldly perspective he has been a failure; from the spiritual perspective he has not succeeded. Apratiṣṭhaḥ — no foothold anywhere. Vimūḍhaḥ — deluded. This is a complete picture of spiritual desolation. The question is not merely academic; every sincere sādhaka fears this outcome. It is the fundamental question about the security of the spiritual path.
commentary.yogananda: The chinnābhram image is one of the most evocative in the Gita. A shred of cloud torn from the main body has no capacity to produce rain — it simply fades. Arjuna fears the spiritually incomplete soul shares this fate: cut off from materialistic fulfillment, cut off from divine realization — lost in the in-between. Vimūḍho brahmaṇaḥ pathi — confused on the path to Brahman. Yoganandaji assured us that no soul is ever truly lost in this way. The very fact that a soul has turned toward God, even imperfectly, leaves an indelible mark on the causal body that draws it back toward the divine in future incarnations. The torn cloud must eventually rejoin the ocean in rain or mist — and so must every soul.
commentary.goyandka: This verse presents the worst-case scenario that Arjuna can envision. Ubhaya-vibhraṣṭa — fallen from both. He has given up worldly activities and enjoyments for yoga; he has then also given up or been unable to complete yoga. He stands in a no-man's land. The chinnābhram simile captures this precisely: a shred of cloud, separated from its mass, has no power to become rain, no endurance to remain, and simply vanishes. Apratiṣṭhaḥ — without any stable support. Vimūḍhaḥ — thoroughly confused, having lost the guidance of both worldly wisdom and spiritual discrimination. This verse completes Arjuna's anguished question, and the two together — 37 and 38 — call forth one of the most reassuring pronouncements in the entire Gita.

verses.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच ।
एतन्मे संशयं कृष्ण छेत्तुमर्हस्यशेषतः ।
त्वदन्यः संशयस्यास्य छेत्ता न ह्युपपद्यते ॥
verses.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca
etan me saṃśayaṃ kṛṣṇa chettum arhasy aśeṣataḥ
tvad-anyaḥ saṃśayasyāsya chettā na hy upapadyate
verses.translation: Arjuna implores with humility and complete surrender: O Krishna, resolve this doubt that dwells in the cave of my heart — dissolve it entirely, without remainder. For I know, with the certainty of the soul recognizing its Higher Self, that no one in all creation is capable of cutting through this fear except You, my divine Teacher, the very Soul of my soul.

word_breakdown.root: sam + √śi (to lie, to rest) — that which lies across both sides; uncertainty
word_breakdown.meaning: doubt / uncertainty — specifically a doubt that agitates, that pulls in two directions at once and gives no peace
to cut / to sever — doubt is like a knot (saṃśaya also means a knot); it must be cut, not untied gradually; the image is of decisive resolution
completely / without any remainder — leaving nothing unresolved; Arjuna does not want a partial answer that might leave secondary doubts
other than You — excluding Krishna from those unable to answer; an implicit affirmation of Krishna's unique omniscience and grace

word_breakdown.root: upa + √pad (to fall, to come about, to be possible)
word_breakdown.meaning: is possible / is appropriate / comes about — literally: no other cutter of this doubt comes about or exists

commentary.dadaji: This one verse is a whole teaching on the Guru-disciple relationship. Arjuna says: 'Tvad-anyaḥ saṃśayasyāsya chettā na hy upapadyate' — no one but You can cut this doubt. He is not saying no one else is smart enough. He is saying: this doubt is in my deepest heart, and only the one who lives in my deepest heart can answer it. Only the Guru who is also the God within can answer the questions that truly matter. And 'aśeṣataḥ' — completely, leaving no residue. This is the right way to come before the Lord with one's troubles: completely, honestly, trusting that He alone can resolve what no amount of human cleverness can. This verse is itself a prayer.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse marks the emotional culmination of Arjuna's inquiry. He has asked his question in two parts — verses 37 and 38 — and now he explicitly surrenders the resolution to Krishna alone. Chettum — to cut. The Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad uses the same image: 'Bhidyate hṛdaya-granthiḥ — the knot of the heart is cut asunder' upon Self-knowledge. A doubt that is merely argued away on the intellectual surface may return; but a doubt cut at the root by the direct insight of a realized teacher is gone for good. 'Tvad-anyaḥ... na upapadyate' — no one other than You. This is the recognition of the Guru's indispensability — not because others lack intellect, but because only the one who has realized the truth can transmit the certainty that dissolves doubt.
commentary.yogananda: In this verse, Arjuna makes the complete surrender of the questioner to the teacher. Note that he has not asked abstractly — he has asked from the ache of personal concern: what happens to people like me, who have faith but struggle? And now he says: only You can cut this. Not merely answer it intellectually, but cut it — with the sword of divine wisdom that leaves no wound of remaining uncertainty. Yoganandaji often said that the highest form of spiritual inquiry is this: not the clever intellectual question designed to impress, but the burning personal question that keeps one awake at night, brought in full vulnerability before the one who knows. Arjuna's surrender here is as beautiful as his question.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's appeal in this verse has three noteworthy features. First, 'chettum arhasi' — 'You are fit to cut' — this is not mere flattery but acknowledgment of Krishna's authority as Brahman Itself. Second, 'aśeṣataḥ' — completely — shows the thoroughness required; a partial answer would only generate further doubt. Third, 'tvad-anyaḥ... na upapadyate' — no one other than You — this exclusive appeal reveals that Arjuna understands the unique status of the Sadguru: only one who has transcended death and rebirth can speak with authority about the fate of the soul after death. The question of what happens to the incomplete yogi is a question about the next world; only the one who knows all worlds can answer it.

verses.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
पार्थ नैवेह नामुत्र विनाशस्तस्य विद्यते ।
न हि कल्याणकृत्कश्चिद् दुर्गतिं तात गच्छति ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
pārtha naiveha nāmutra vināśas tasya vidyate
na hi kalyāṇa-kṛt kaścid durgatiṃ tāta gacchati
verses.translation: The Lord speaks with the warmth of divine certainty: O beloved Partha, there is no destruction for that soul — not in this world, not in any world beyond. Hear Me and be at peace: not one who has sincerely turned toward the Good, not one who has ever genuinely reached for God, ever meets a bad end. This is the law written in the heart of the cosmos by Love itself. No sincere spiritual effort is ever lost.

word_breakdown.root: vi + √naś (to perish, to be lost, to be destroyed)
word_breakdown.meaning: destruction / perdition / utter loss — the feared fate of the fallen yogi; Krishna's answer is its direct negation

word_breakdown.root: kalyāṇa (auspicious, good, virtuous, beneficial) + √kṛ (to do, to make)
word_breakdown.meaning: one who does good / doer of the auspicious — includes not just ethics but all sincere spiritual effort; any turning toward the higher is 'kalyāṇa'

word_breakdown.root: dur (bad, evil, difficult) + gati (destination, movement, from √gam)
word_breakdown.meaning: evil destiny / miserable end / bad fate — the opposite of what is promised; the fallen yogi will definitively NOT reach this

word_breakdown.root: tāta (affectionate address: dear child, dear one)
word_breakdown.grammatical_form: Masculine noun, vocative, singular (term of endearment)
word_breakdown.meaning: O beloved / O dear one / O my child — one of the most tender forms of address in Sanskrit; Krishna's deep love for Arjuna pours through this single word
certainly not / absolutely not / not at all — the emphatic eva removes all ambiguity; destruction is unequivocally ruled out

commentary.dadaji: Tāta — this word. This is the whole Gita in one word. Tāta means 'my dear child.' The Lord of the universe calls Arjuna — calls each of us — 'my dear child.' And He says: no destruction. None. Neither here nor there. And then the universal law that should be written on every heart: 'na hi kalyāṇa-kṛt kaścid durgatiṃ gacchati' — no one who does good ever comes to grief. Not some people. Not most people. No one. Ever. If you have turned toward God — even once, even imperfectly, even with a wandering mind — that turning is kalyāṇa. It is written in the ledger of eternity. No amount of falling can erase it. This is why we say Bhagwan is karuṇāmaya — full of compassion beyond all measure.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This is one of the most liberating verses in all of scripture. Krishna's answer is an absolute, unequivocal assurance: na vināśaḥ vidyate — destruction simply does not exist for such a person. Not in this life, not in the hereafter. The logic is dharmic: spiritual progress is not like money that can be lost. It is inscribed in the subtle and causal bodies of the jīva and persists across births. 'Kalyāṇa-kṛt' — one who does good, who pursues the auspicious, who orients toward the Divine — such a one cannot ultimately fail. The word 'tāta' — dear child — is deeply moving here. It is not the tone of a theological pronouncement but of a parent comforting an anxious child. The Absolute speaks as Love.
commentary.yogananda: Na hi kalyāṇa-kṛt kaścid durgatiṃ tāta gacchati — not one single doer of good, ever, comes to an evil end. This is the cosmic law of spiritual gravity: the soul that has turned toward God is drawn by that turning forever forward and upward. It may take many lives, many rebirths in progressive circumstances — as described in the following verses — but the direction is set. Yoganandaji taught that this is precisely what resurrection means in the deepest sense: the soul that has been touched by divine grace cannot truly die. It rises again and again, in body after body, in life after life, until the journey is complete. Tāta — beloved — the Lord uses the most intimate word to deliver the most universal promise.
commentary.goyandka: This verse constitutes one of the most definitive assurances in the entire Bhagavad Gītā. Krishna's answer is direct and absolute. The word 'naiva' — certainly not — leaves no room for exception or qualification. The fear expressed in verses 37-38, that the failed yogi might be utterly lost like a torn cloud, is completely dispelled. The reason given is the fundamental spiritual law encapsulated in 'na kalyāṇa-kṛt kaścid durgatiṃ gacchati': no doer of good ever reaches a bad end. Spiritual effort, once made with faith, cannot be negated. It accumulates across lives. The word 'tāta' — a term of the deepest affection — reveals that this is not a cold legal guarantee but a promise from the Lord to His own child. The following verses will explain the positive destiny in detail.

verses.sanskrit:
प्राप्य पुण्यकृतां लोकानुषित्वा शाश्वतीः समाः ।
शुचीनां श्रीमतां गेहे योगभ्रष्टोऽभिजायते ॥
verses.transliteration:
prāpya puṇya-kṛtāṃ lokān uṣitvā śāśvatīḥ samāḥ
śucīnāṃ śrīmatāṃ gehe yoga-bhraṣṭo 'bhijāyate
verses.translation: The incomplete yogi first ascends — by the merit of sincere spiritual striving — to radiant inner planes where the righteous dwell, resting there through immeasurable, blessed years. Then, when those luminous realms have been enjoyed, the soul descends again to earth — but not into darkness. Divine Grace arranges a beautiful return: birth into a home of purity and abundance, where the Spirit can grow.

word_breakdown.meaning: of the righteous / of those who have performed meritorious deeds
immeasurable / many long-lasting (years)

word_breakdown.grammatical_form: Adjective used as noun, masculine, genitive, plural
word_breakdown.meaning: of the pure / of those who are spiritually clean
the fallen yogi / one who has slipped from the path of yoga

word_breakdown.grammatical_form: Verb, present tense, passive, third person singular
word_breakdown.meaning: is born / takes birth — is reborn into

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji used to say with quiet reassurance: 'Not one step taken toward God is ever wasted — not one.' This verse is Krishna's own guarantee of that truth. The yoga-bhraṣṭa — the one who tried and fell — does not fall into darkness. He rises first to the luminous worlds of the righteous, enjoys those fruits of sincere spiritual effort, and then descends again into a life of purity and prosperity. The word 'śucīnāṃ śrīmatāṃ' — pure and prosperous — tells us something sweet: God arranges a beautiful cradle for the returning soul. Born into a noble family with spiritual atmosphere, the fallen yogi finds himself once again in the right environment to resume what he left incomplete. Divine compassion leaves no soul abandoned.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The Vedantic reading of this verse illuminates the cosmic justice woven into the structure of karma and rebirth. The yoga-bhraṣṭa first reaps the positive fruits of sincere spiritual effort — the puṇya-kṛtāṃ lokān, the higher planes of existence — because no action performed in God-consciousness goes unrewarded. Then, after those fruits are exhausted, the soul descends again, but not randomly. It is drawn to a śucī (pure) and śrīmān (prosperous) household — an environment that will support its next attempt at liberation. This is the śāstra's compassionate teaching: the law of karma does not punish sincerity; it creates the conditions for its eventual fulfillment.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda teaches that after the death of the body, the soul does not immediately reincarnate. It first passes through the astral realms — here referred to as the 'worlds of the righteous' — where it experiences the refined states it cultivated in meditation. These astral sojourns can span vast time periods. When the soul descends again, it is drawn by its own vibratory affinity to a family whose spiritual atmosphere resonates with its inner development. Being born in the house of the śucī (pure) corresponds to an environment rich with sattva — where meditation, devotion, and dharmic living are natural. The soul is thus given every advantage to resume its journey.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka notes that this verse answers an implicit anxiety: will the sincere yogi who fails suffer the same fate as the irreligious? Absolutely not, says the Lord. The yoga-bhraṣṭa first enjoys the puṇya-lokas — the planes earned by righteous living — for 'śāśvatīḥ samāḥ,' an almost incalculable span of time. Only then does he return to earth, and even that return is arranged by cosmic law into a śucī (morally pure) and śrīmat (materially comfortable) household. Such a birth gives him both the inner orientation and the outer leisure to resume sādhanā. This is the systematic benevolence of dharma for those who sincerely undertake its highest path.

verses.sanskrit:
अथ वा योगिनामेव कुले भवति धीमताम् ।
एतद्धि दुर्लभतरं लोके जन्म यदीदृशम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
atha vā yoginām eva kule bhavati dhīmatām
etad dhi durlabha-taraṃ loke janma yad īdṛśam
verses.translation: Or — and this is the rarest, most exquisite gift of karma — the soul is born directly into a family of wise yogis, a lineage alive with meditation, devotion, and the direct knowledge of God. Such a birth, says the Lord, is the most difficult of all to obtain in this world. To breathe the sacred atmosphere of realized souls from one's first breath is an incalculable blessing beyond all comparison.

in the family / in the lineage of

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji would pause meaningfully whenever he quoted this verse. 'Think,' he would say, 'how rare it is to be born in a home where someone meditates, where God's name is spoken at the dinner table, where the atmosphere is saturated with sādhanā.' The word 'dhīmatām' — wise yogis — captures something extraordinary: not merely a family that follows ritual, but one where wisdom and direct inner practice are alive. This birth, Krishna says, is durlabhataram — rarer even than the pious householder's birth of verse 41. To be born where spiritual intelligence surrounds you from your first breath is the greatest gift karma can bestow. If you have had even a glimpse of such a home, honor it deeply.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Two possibilities are offered for the yoga-bhraṣṭa's rebirth: the house of the pure and prosperous (v41), or — presented here as a second and higher alternative — the kula of yogis themselves. The word 'eva' (indeed, certainly) emphasizes that this second birth is specifically within an active lineage of practitioners, not merely a morally upright family. The superlative 'durlabhataram' — more difficult to obtain than anything else in the world — signals that Krishna considers this birth the supreme arrangement karma can make. From the Advaita perspective, it means being born into an environment where the highest teaching of non-duality is breathed in from childhood.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda often emphasized the inestimable importance of the spiritual environment one is born into. He called it 'spiritual heredity' — the subtle transmission of yogic attainment that flows through a lineage of sincere practitioners. To be born in the kula of yoginām dhīmatām is to inherit a vibratory patrimony that immediately supports meditation, renunciation, and God-realization. The soul that has earned such a birth enters life already resonant with the inner states it had previously cultivated. This is why Yogananda taught that choosing one's spiritual community carefully in this life creates the conditions for the most auspicious rebirth in the next.
commentary.goyandka: This verse presents a gradation. The previous verse described rebirth in a śucī-śrīmat household — morally pure and comfortable. This verse presents an even more exalted option: birth directly in the family of wise yogis. Goyandka emphasizes the word 'dhīmatām' — it is not enough to be yogis in name; these are dhī-mān, endowed with discriminative intelligence, which points to jñāna-yoga alongside dhyāna-yoga. Such a family transmits not only religious habit but viveka (discrimination). The declaration 'etad dhi durlabhataram loke' is Krishna's own statement of how rare and precious this destiny is — it surpasses all worldly blessings.

verses.sanskrit:
तत्र तं बुद्धिसंयोगं लभते पौर्वदेहिकम् ।
यतते च ततो भूयः संसिद्धौ कुरुनन्दन ॥
verses.transliteration:
tatra taṃ buddhi-saṃyogaṃ labhate paurva-dehikam
yatate ca tato bhūyaḥ saṃsiddhau kuru-nandana
verses.translation: In that auspicious birth, the soul is reunited with the spiritual intelligence it had cultivated in previous lives — the subtle attainments of meditation, the cultivated sensitivity of the heart, all the inner currency of past devotion — flowing back like a remembered light. And from that reawakened foundation, the soul strives again with fresh momentum toward the supreme perfection, O joy of the Kurus.

word_breakdown.meaning: reconnection with intelligence / re-linking to the spiritual discernment of the previous life
belonging to the previous body / from the former life — the accumulated spiritual capital of the past birth
in perfection / toward complete spiritual attainment — the final goal of liberation
O joy of the Kurus — a loving address to Arjuna as the delight of his noble lineage

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji called this verse 'the proof of God's perfect memory.' Nothing is lost. The buddhi-saṃyoga — the reconnection with one's previous spiritual intelligence — happens automatically when the soul takes birth in the right environment. A child born in a yogi's home who shows precocious spiritual sensitivity, who is naturally drawn to meditation without being taught — that is this verse made visible. Dadaji often told the story of young saints who seemed to already know what they had not yet learned, because they had learned it before. The phrase 'kuru-nandana' — joy of the Kurus — is a tender aside from Krishna to Arjuna: 'This is your heritage too. Every step you take now carries forward into eternity.'
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The crucial term here is 'buddhi-saṃyoga' — the re-union of consciousness with its previously cultivated spiritual intelligence. Vedanta teaches that the subtle body (sūkṣma-śarīra) carries the saṃskāras — the impressions — from one birth to the next. When the soul takes birth in a spiritually charged environment, those saṃskāras are reactivated more rapidly. This is why certain souls seem to leap ahead in a single lifetime: they are not beginning anew but resuming. The verb 'labhate' (obtains, recovers) is precise — it is not earned fresh but recovered, like a debt repaid. From there, the striving toward 'saṃsiddhau' — complete perfection — resumes with accumulated momentum.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda described this process as the soul 'picking up the thread.' Each earnest meditation, each moment of divine contact, creates a groove — a channel — in the superconscious mind. Death cannot erase that groove. In the new body, when the child first encounters meditation or devotion, those ancient channels reopen with astonishing ease. Yogananda pointed to the lives of great saints who, from childhood, displayed mystical states that ordinary religious training could never produce in a lifetime. This is buddhi-saṃyoga — the divine reunion with one's own highest self. The address 'kuru-nandana' carries warmth: Krishna is reassuring Arjuna that sincere effort now will make his future lives blessed.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka's classical commentary focuses on the precision of 'paurva-dehikam' — specifically belonging to the previous body, meaning the accumulated discriminative intelligence and spiritual refinement of the prior life. This is distinct from general puṇya (merit), which anyone may accumulate. The yoga-bhraṣṭa's buddhi carries the specific flavor of his practice: his degree of vairāgya, his meditation depth, his understanding of śāstra. All of this re-manifests. The phrase 'yatate ca tato bhūyaḥ' — 'he strives again from that point' — indicates continuity of effort across the discontinuity of death, which Goyandka presents as the śāstra's definitive answer to the anxiety about spiritual progress being cut short.

verses.sanskrit:
पूर्वाभ्यासेन तेनैव ह्रियते ह्यवशोऽपि सः ।
जिज्ञासुरपि योगस्य शब्दब्रह्मातिवर्तते ॥

pūrvābhyāsena tenaiva hriyate hy avaśo 'pi saḥ
jijñāsur api yogasya śabda-brahmātivartate
verses.translation: The very current of former practice sweeps the soul forward — effortlessly, irresistibly — even without the conscious will of the new incarnation. Something deeper than memory, a spiritual gravity, draws the soul back toward God. And even the soul who has only begun to ask, who is only now first wondering about yoga and its deeper mysteries — that sincere inquirer has already gone beyond the outer letter of all scripture.

without will / involuntarily — even without conscious effort or self-direction

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji loved this verse with great tenderness. 'Even avaśaḥ — helplessly, without trying — the soul is pulled toward God by what it once practiced.' He would say it like a reassurance to struggling seekers: 'Your sincere practice today is building a current. One day, in this life or the next, you will find yourself drawn toward God with a pull you cannot explain and do not need to explain — it will simply be so.' And then the beautiful second line: even a mere jijñāsu — someone who is only curious about yoga, who has only begun to wonder — already surpasses the exoteric Vedic path. The inner search, however tentative, is greater than perfect ritual observance.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse contains one of the most liberating statements in all of Vedantic literature: 'śabda-brahmātivartate' — he transcends śabda-brahman. Śabda-brahman refers to the Vedas in their ritualistic, karma-kāṇḍa aspect — the path of prescribed action, sacrifice, and worldly fruit. Even a jijñāsu — a mere spiritual inquirer, not yet a perfected yogi — has already gone beyond this level. Shankaracharya reads this as placing jñāna-yoga and dhyāna-yoga categorically above karma-kāṇḍa. The deeper point is that sincere inner inquiry operates in a dimension that external ritual, however precise, cannot reach. Practice carries its own momentum, pulling the soul forward even when the ego does not cooperate.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda called pūrvābhyāsa — prior practice — 'spiritual gravity.' Just as physical gravity pulls matter downward without requiring the matter's consent, spiritual gravity pulls the prepared soul toward its source without requiring the ego's assent. 'Avaśo 'pi' — even without will — is Yogananda's proof that grace and karma work together: the sincere meditator builds a gravitational field around his own soul that eventually draws him home. The second half of the verse is equally profound: the jijñāsu — the seeker who only asks the question — has already exceeded the śabda-brahman path, because the question itself arises from the inner Self calling to itself, which no external ritual can replicate.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka draws a careful distinction in this verse between two types of yoga-bhraṣṭa mentioned across verses 41-44. The first type (v41) is born into a pious household, the second and higher type (v42) into a yogi's household. For both, prior practice exerts an irresistible pull — 'hriyate hy avaśo 'pi saḥ' — he is carried forward even without his own volition. This is the śāstra's teaching that saṃskāras (spiritual impressions) are not destroyed by death. The remarkable claim that the jijñāsu surpasses śabda-brahman is Goyandka's evidence that the Gita places direct inquiry into the nature of the self above the exoteric Vedic path of ritual and reward.

verses.sanskrit:
प्रयत्नाद्यतमानस्तु योगी संशुद्धकिल्बिषः ।
अनेकजन्मसंसिद्धस्ततो याति परां गतिम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
prayatnād yatamānas tu yogī saṃśuddha-kilbiṣaḥ
aneka-janma-saṃsiddhas tato yāti parāṃ gatim
verses.translation: The yogi who strives earnestly — life after devoted life, layer after layer of impurity dissolved in the sacred fire of practice, gradually refined and ripened across the long arc of many births — arrives at last at the supreme Goal. Every sincere incarnation brings the soul closer. Every honest meditation burns away another veil. The journey is long, but God is patient, and the destination is utterly certain.

word_breakdown.meaning: with effort / through earnest endeavor — because of diligent striving
purified of all sins / completely cleansed of impurity — one whose entire stock of negative karma is dissolved
perfected through many births / ripened over numerous lifetimes of sincere practice
